title: Jersey Shore's The Situation talks prison with Fyre Festival's Billy McFarland
text:
Billy’s criminal missions have continued behind bars (Picture: Getty)

Jersey Shore star The Situation has claimed that Billy McFarland was put in solitary confinement in prison after the Fyre Festival scammer reportedly snuck in an illegal recording device.

The Situation – real name Mike Sorrentino – recently served an eight-month sentence for tax evasion charges.

While in prison, the TV personality somehow ended up running into Fyre’s scammer-in-chief Billy, the unlikable antagonist of Netflix and Hulu’s documentaries on the 2017 failed event.

So, has the repeat fraudster learnt his lesson and become a reformed character in prison? Not according to The Situation.

‘He would say “hi,” but he wasn’t in my group of friends,’ Mike told his Jersey Shore co-star Snooki on the It’s Happening With Snooki and Joey podcast, adding that he’d ‘played against him in basketball and softball maybe’.

However Billy is said to have found himself in trouble after sneaking in contraband items, getting himself thrown into solitary confinement, or the SHU (Solitary Housing Unit).

Billy with rapper Ja Rule in Netflix’s FYRE: The Greatest Party That Never Happened (Picture: Netflix)

If we’ve learnt anything from Orange Is The New Black, it’s that that is not a place you want to go.

‘He supposedly smuggled in some sort of recording device, and he was caught with it,’ The Situation speculated.

‘They said he was trying to record high-profile inmates and they threw him in the SHU. They sent him to a worse prison, I think, recently. That’s a bonehead move right there.’

You’re telling us.

‘I don’t even know why you’d be trying to record in there,’ Mike said, theorising: ‘Maybe he was trying to write a book.’

Well, given that Billy is currently 18 months into a six-year sentence for his role orchestrating the influencer festival car crash that was Fyre Festival, we suspect that we might have to wait a while for his memoirs to be released.

Still, is it bad to admit that we would actually read it?
